Lambda Calculus

Simple Reduction Examples

Posted by Bradley Post on April 12, 2018

I’ve studying THE Lambda Calculus lately, and I realized that there isn’t exactly a wealth of examples for reducing expressions in -calculus.I might just be a dummy, but I find that looking at examples really helps me wrap my head things. So, in the interest of helping someone else who might be struggling, I have decided to give a brief explanantion of -calculus, and provide some simple examples of reduction that would help a beginner get going.

What is Lambda Calculus?

Simply put, -calculus is a system of mathematics based only on applying functions to other functions. If you’ve ever heard of Peano Arithemtic, it’s a pursit in a similar vein. The goal is to create as simple a formal system as possible in that can still be used to solve complex problems. In the case of Peano arithmetic, we show that we only need a few axioms about natural numbers to do prove a whole bunch of stuff. Lambda calculus does the same thing, but instead of proving things about numbers, we can prove things about computation. The system can be shown to be Turing complete, and allows us to determine whether functions are computable by algorithm. Though it can behave like a Turing machine, calculus generally feels more like working with a high-level programming language. In fact, many programming languages have been developed based on lambda calculus. They are classified as functional languages, and they include:Haskell (named after Haskell Curry), F#, O-Caml, and Lisp. There are functional aspects of many other programming languages.

Some Good Resources

The basic concepts of -calculus were kind of hard for me to wrap my head around, so in the interest of helping someone who may stumble upon this page, I have a few links that might with understanding the basics: This one has some good illustrations, but the bird analogy becomes very tedious: http://dkeenan.com/Lambda/ A lot of people seem to think this is clever, but I haven’t seen anyone saying they actually learned -calculus with it: http://worrydream.com/AlligatorEggs/ I’ve been working through this textbook It’s very mathy, which is probably why I had so much trouble to start. But, if you like proof based exercises and mathematical rigour, this is a good option: http://www.cse.chalmers.se/research/group/logic/TypesSS05/Extra/geuvers.pdf Honestly, the thing that helped me the most was this Stack Overflow response: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/34140819/lambda-calculus-reduction-steps In any case, if you’re here, you probably have a resource that you’re working with.

Examples

I’m going to writing these examples based on the notation given in the textbook above. This may be slightly different than what you’re using, so I’ll try to make note of how notation may differ.     Firstly, I’ll point out that a lot of resources write out a lambda for each bound variable (i.e. ), but it’s fine to drop the extra lambdas and just assume every variable before the “.” is bound. The first thing we need to do is figure out where the most deeply nested application is. That would be . So, we’ll apply our function to . We can write this as . The := is the substitution operator, so we’re substituting every in with the variable . This then reduces to . This is known formally as Beta-Reduction. Now we have:     If we remove the unnecessary parentheses, we get as our next application. Now, we substitute and get . This leaves:   or   which is a function that swaps the order of two parameters.

This is a simple example to showcase Alpha Conversion: This expression can be reduced by substituting the ’s in for , or so it seems. The problem is that the function we are substituting into already has a variable named , and this is not necessarily the same as the on the outside. If you’re familiar with programming, it’s the equivalent of declaring variables of the same name in a different namespaces. Fortunately, -conversion lets us change variable names. So, all we have to do is change the on the outside to something else, like , , or . The name doesn’t matter. So:

Encodings

So, one of the big things people like to do with lambda calculus is make encodings that do things similar to numbers or logical operators. It’s kind of boring to just reduce these expressions for no reason, so I’ll be using some encodings for my examples. A few simple ones are encodings for True, False, and Not. True = False = Not =

So, now that we have these, let’s evaluate some logical expressions using -calculus, : not false (not)() false true false true Which is the function we defined as true. So, we can see that applying our not function to the false function returns the true function. Isn’t that neat?

Let’s test out something a little more complicated: not (not true) true)(not true) ((not true) false) true ((( xy.((x false) true) true) false)( true) Note the number of parentheses, this is how we can tell we are applying the “not” function to the second “true”. Also, in the step before, we can see the “not” is being applied to that “true”. It can get hard to keep track of the parentheses, so it’s important to be aware of what you’re doing over all the steps.

(((true false) true) false) true ((( xy.x false) true) false) true ((( y.false) true) false) true ((false) false) true xy.y (false) (true) true

It worked again! That’s all for now. I’m planning on making a post on Church Numerals soon.
